thread.title: Sunnyside plant owner pleads guilty to selling tainted fruit juice | News | cnhinews.com
thread.title_full: Sunnyside plant owner pleads guilty to selling tainted fruit juice | News | cnhinews.com

author: JASPER KENZO SUNDEEN Yakima Herald-Republic
title: Sunnyside plant owner pleads guilty to selling tainted fruit juice | News | cnhinews.com
text:
The owner of Sunnyside-based fruit and juice company Valley Processing Inc. pleaded guilty to violating federal food safety laws, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office.
Mary Ann Bliesner, 83, who owned the now-closed plant, pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors: failing to register a food facility with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and conspiracy to introduce misbranded and tainted fruit juice into interstate commerce.
Some of the tainted juice was sold to be used in the National School Lunch Program, a news release from U.S. Attorney's Office said.
Spokane-based attorney Carl Oreskovich represented Bliesner. He said Bliesner was responsible for company actions but never intended to distribute the tainted juice.
"That was not a large quantity in terms of the company's business," Oreskovich said. "It was certainly something Mary Ann (Bliesner) did not want to happen, but it did happen."
Oreskovich said Valley Processing was a large business with more than 100 employees and multiple levels of management.
"There were directions that were given and not followed. Things got slack and there was juice that got produced that should not have been produced," Oreskovich said.
He added that Bliesner has since retired. Bliesner agreed to pay $742,139 and will be sentenced on March 26.
Plea agreement between Mary Ann Bliesner and U.S. Attorney's Office
FDA investigators found that Valley Processing, or VPI, was blending old and improperly stored juice concentrate with newer juice concentrate and then selling the new mixture to customers, the release said.
“VPI admitted that it blended grape juice concentrate, which was stored outside the VPI facility for years and exposed to the elements, with newer grape juice concentrate, and sold the resulting blended grape juice product to unsuspecting customers as if it were new product,” the release said. “VPI sold at least some of this contaminated product to customers who provided grape juice for the National School Lunch Program, which provides free or reduced-cost lunches to children.”
The release said the juice concentrate was contaminated after being stored improperly and Valley Processing employees initially stopped inspectors from looking at the vats by placing caution tape over the entrance to the storage room with the older concentrate and telling inspectors the facility was unsafe to enter.
“FDA investigators later learned about the vats and, after entering the room, observed grape juice concentrate that testing later confirmed was contaminated with bird and rodent feces, fur, insects, decaying remains of animals, mold, yeast and other contaminants,” the release said. “FDA inspectors also observed and photographed a live rat walking across the hardened crust that had formed on top of the grape juice concentrate.”
Oreskovich acknowledged the poor storage conditions, but said that putrid juice was never intended to be used. A small amount was mixed in and sold, he added, and no one got sick.
"There was not one case, that I'm aware of, of anyone who consumed Valley (Processing) juice getting sick," Oreskovich said.
The news release said the facility where juice was produced was not registered with the FDA.
In 2020, Valley Processing was sued for producing juices tainted with inorganic arsenic and moldy fruit. Bliesner agreed to an injunction that stopped the company from producing fruit juice. Federal prosecutors charged Bliesner and Valley Processing with fraud and violations of food safety laws in 2022.
FDA officials said Valley Processing’s actions put consumers and schoolchildren at risk. Valley Processing is now closed.
Oreskovich said Bliesner was a pioneer for women in the industry and this case was an unfortunate end to her career.
Jasper Kenzo Sundeen can be reached at jsundeen@yakimaherald.com .
Originally published on yakimaherald.com , part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange .
